keyTakeAways: Americans are largely unenthused about Trump’s handling of the Gaza ceasefire deal, despite initial optimism or praise from some critics.
Trump’s overall approval rating has declined to a second-term low, with 61% disapproving compared to 37% approving, indicating a significant loss of public trust.
Public disapproval of Trump on economic issues has reached a new low, with 62% disapproving of his handling of inflation and the cost of living, and a 13-point negative net approval on the economy.
Americans show growing pessimism about the economy, with only 32% expecting improvement in the economy and 31% expecting wage growth over the next year.
Employed Americans are increasingly concerned about job security, with only 52% saying they are not at all worried about losing their jobs — a decline from previous years.
Foreign policy issues, including the Gaza deal, are ranked very low in public concern, with only 4% of Americans considering international events the most important issue facing the country.
A majority of Americans (three-fourths) believe Trump has not focused enough on lowering prices, indicating economic concerns outweigh foreign policy gains.
The Gaza ceasefire deal appears to have had little lasting domestic impact, reinforcing that public perception is shaped more by economic performance than foreign policy achievements.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite the announcement of a Gaza ceasefire deal, which some initially viewed as a major diplomatic victory for President Donald Trump, public enthusiasm in the United States has been minimal. Polls show Trump's approval ratings remain at or below their lowest points in his second term, especially on economic issues, where disapproval reaches new highs. Americans show little interest in foreign policy matters, with only 4% prioritizing international events. Instead, concerns about inflation, rising prices, job security, and economic decline dominate public sentiment. Even the temporary boost in approval on the Gaza deal appears fragile, as public trust remains deeply tied to domestic economic performance. The article concludes that Trump’s political standing is not bolstered by foreign policy achievements, but rather undermined by persistent economic failures.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
